tetsu-ji =3D surface of the iron plate

yakite shitate =3D a surface finish=
 resembling the glaze on pottery.  Produced by putting the finished plate b=
ack into the furnace and allowing the surface to melt slightly.

ji-mon =3D=
 a pattern of hammer marks on the surface of the tsuba.

tetkotsu =3D "bone=
s." Lumps produced as the result of the steel being made of a mixture of ir=
ons of differing hardness. A key feature in the eyes of tsuba aficionadoes.=


mimi =3D the edge.  



What you want to do is get hold of a copy of:

Al=
an L. Harvie (editor), Tsuba - An Aesthetic Study by Kazutaro Torigoye and =
Robert E. Hayes, translated from the Tsuba Geijutsu-K=F4 of Kazutaro Torigo=
ye, Northern California Japanese Sword Club, N.P., March, 2000.  



in whi=
ch you will find a handy glossary, as well as a course in tsuba fundamental=
s.  It is available via:



http://www.ncjsc.org/
